Package io.github.motetpaper.temperature

Interface Temperature

All Known Implementing Classes:
Celsius, Fahrenheit, Kelvin, Rankine
public interface Temperature
Represents Temperature scales and conversions

  • Method Details

    • toString

      String toString()
      Returns decimal-formatted string representation of this object with units.

      A few words about implementation. The precision of the input value is preserved, and available in the .getValue() method.

      The ".as" methods (e.g., .asCelsius()) creates new Temperature objects allowing the use of .toString() to return the values as decimal-formatted strings (as specified in the Temperature interface), along with familiar temperature scale units.

      EXAMPLE: "25°C"

      Overrides:
      toString in class Object
      Returns:
      decimal-formatted value with units.

    • getValue

      double getValue()
      Returns the input (set) value of the Temperature object.

      This preserve the precision. If you want decimal-formatted output, use .toString instead.

      Returns:
      the Temperature value

    • setValue

      Temperature setValue(double aValue)
      Sets the value for this Temperature object; then, returns this object.

      Most users of this package will only deal with temperatures at or above absolute zero. To that point, any value below absolute zero is beyond the scope of this object's model.

      This function expects a valid temperature value at or above absolute zero. If the input value is less than absolute zero, the value will be clamped at absolute zero. A warning will be printed using System.err

      Parameters:
      aValue - a valid temperature above absolute zero
      Returns:
      this Temperature object
